Psychology_448_r.News Finding: They also found that while older bipolar disorder patients had significantly accelerated epigenetic aging compared to controls, no difference was found in younger patients.
Psychology_448_r.Paper Finding: This might be one of the reasons why we only detected significant differences in epigenetic aging in older subjects, especially considering the key role proposed for chronic stress and the high rates of unhealthy lifestyles seen in BD patients .
Psychology_448_r.News Context: "Controlling these factors is just as important as taking medications," Fries said. They also found that while older bipolar disorder patients had significantly accelerated epigenetic aging compared to controls, no difference was found in younger patients. "We believe a difference wasn't detected in younger patients because they haven't had as much exposure to stressful events," Fries said.
Psychology_448_r.Paper Context: In line with previous results , our current findings suggest that DNAm age might represent a better aging marker than the commonly used telomere length, particularly in older individuals. This might be one of the reasons why we only detected significant differences in epigenetic aging in older subjects, especially considering the key role proposed for chronic stress and the high rates of unhealthy lifestyles seen in BD patients . Our findings suggest that accelerated epigenetic aging in BD may be at least partially associated with an increase in mtDNA copy number.
Psychology_448_r.text: ['Finding: They also found that while older bipolar disorder patients had significantly accelerated epigenetic aging compared to controls, no difference was found in younger patients.']
Psychology_448_r.displayed_text: Finding: They also found that while older bipolar disorder patients had significantly accelerated epigenetic aging compared to controls, no difference was found in younger patients.

Psychology_tweet_217_r.News Finding: Why is it good to enter the workforce in a time of recession?
Psychology_tweet_217_r.Paper Finding: Across three studies, well-educated graduates who entered the workforce during economic downturns were more satisfied with their current jobs than those who entered during more prosperous economic times.
Psychology_tweet_217_r.News Context: Why is it good to enter the workforce in a time of recession?
Psychology_tweet_217_r.Paper Context: Across three studies, well-educated graduates who entered the workforce during economic downturns were more satisfied with their current jobs than those who entered during more prosperous economic times. Study 1 showed that economic conditions at college graduation predicted later job satisfaction even after accounting for different industry and occupational choices. Study 2 replicated these results and found that recession-era graduates were more satisfied with their jobs both early and later in their careers and even when they earned less money.
Psychology_tweet_217_r.text: ['Finding: Why is it good to enter the workforce in a time of recession? ']
Psychology_tweet_217_r.displayed_text: Finding: Why is it good to enter the workforce in a time of recession?

Psychology_tweet_217_p.News Context: Why is it good to enter the workforce in a time of recession?

Psychology_275_r.News Finding: For example, in one experiment, people felt more environmentally conscious after they received a behaviorally targeted ad for a "green" product.
Psychology_275_r.Paper Finding: The results of study 3 replicate previous results by showing that ads identified as behaviorally targeted can affect consumer self-perceptions and hence behavior.
Psychology_275_r.News Context: For example, in one experiment, people felt more environmentally conscious after they received a behaviorally targeted ad for a "green" product. "The power of a behaviorally targeted ad for a green product isn't just that it persuades you to buy the advertised product. It actually makes you feel more environmentally conscious and can change your behavior," said Rebecca Walker Reczek, co-author of the study and associate professor of marketing at The Ohio State University's Fisher College of Business.
Psychology_275_r.Paper Context: , and this effect was not present when the order of the mediators was reversed (b ¼ .0046, SE ¼ .02, 95% CI, À.0297 to .0607). The results of study 3 replicate previous results by showing that ads identified as behaviorally targeted can affect consumer self-perceptions and hence behavior. Specifically, consumers receiving a behaviorally targeted ad for an environmentally friendly "green" product viewed themselves as possessing stronger green consumption values.
Psychology_275_r.text: ['Finding: For example, in one experiment, people felt more environmentally conscious after they received a behaviorally targeted ad for a "green" product.']
Psychology_275_r.displayed_text: Finding: For example, in one experiment, people felt more environmentally conscious after they received a behaviorally targeted ad for a "green" product.

Psychology_503_r.News Finding: While it's true that people are generally averse to harming others, the bottom line is that people don't feel this way all the time."
Psychology_503_r.Paper Finding: c, 26 When the out-group or one of its members suffers a misfortune, this sense of inferiority-and we argue, resulting envious prejudice-leads to intergroup schadenfreude.
Psychology_503_r.News Context: "We found that surprising because we weren't certain participants would self report that. While it's true that people are generally averse to harming others, the bottom line is that people don't feel this way all the time." Again, the findings matched earlier experiments -- participants rated the articles associated with disgust and envy with less warmth than the pride or pity scenarios.
Psychology_503_r.Paper Context: 50 can make salient one's own group's relative inferiority, generating hostile, group-based envy. c, 26 When the out-group or one of its members suffers a misfortune, this sense of inferiority-and we argue, resulting envious prejudice-leads to intergroup schadenfreude. People generally prefer their own in-group to outgroups, 30 but not all out-groups are equivalent.

Psychology_214_r.News Finding: The researchers found that closing the eyes helped the participants remember both audial and visual information.
Psychology_214_r.Paper Finding: The findings extend previous research in showing that the eye-closure instruction can still be effective when witnesses are interviewed repeatedly, and that it can facilitate the elicitation of new information.
Psychology_214_r.News Context: Having a good relationship with the interviewer also helped people answer more questions about the crime correctly, but if the person closed his or her eyes, the recall was effective regardless of the rapport the person felt with the interviewer. The researchers found that closing the eyes helped the participants remember both audial and visual information. The researchers found that closing your eyes during an investigation is likely to make you feel less comfortable unless you have built up a good rapport with the questioner.
Psychology_214_r.Paper Context: Conclusions. The findings extend previous research in showing that the eye-closure instruction can still be effective when witnesses are interviewed repeatedly, and that it can facilitate the elicitation of new information. Thus, the eye-closure instruction constitutes a simple and time-efficient interview tool for police interviewers.
Psychology_214_r.text: ['Finding: The researchers found that closing the eyes helped the participants remember both audial and visual information.']
Psychology_214_r.displayed_text: Finding: The researchers found that closing the eyes helped the participants remember both audial and visual information.

Psychology_tweet_8_r.News Finding: In-school music training in adolescence might accelerate neurodevelopment and improve literacy.   (£)
Psychology_tweet_8_r.Paper Finding: Phonological awareness improved in both training groups from year 1 to year 4, but these gains were larger in the adolescents who underwent in-school music training.
Psychology_tweet_8_r.News Context: In-school music training in adolescence might accelerate neurodevelopment and improve literacy.   (£)
Psychology_tweet_8_r.Paper Context: An increase in the N1/P1 amplitude ratio from year 1 to year 4, known to emerge in adolescence , was observed in the music group but had not yet emerged in the JROTC group. Phonological awareness improved in both training groups from year 1 to year 4, but these gains were larger in the adolescents who underwent in-school music training. Two other language tests, phonological memory and rapid naming, showed no group differences.
Psychology_tweet_8_r.text: ['Finding: In-school music training in adolescence might accelerate neurodevelopment and improve literacy. (£)']
Psychology_tweet_8_r.displayed_text: Finding: In-school music training in adolescence might accelerate neurodevelopment and improve literacy. (£)
